|title=To Europa! Mission to Jupiter's Moon Gains Support in Congress |author=Nola Taylor Redd | date=November 5, 2014 | accessdate=August 31, 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2015/0202-its-official-we-are-on-the-way-to-europa-fy2016.html | title=It's Official: We're On the Way to Europa |first=Casey |last=Dreier | date=3 February 2015 | accessdate=8 February 2015}} The executive branch has also granted $30 million for preliminary studies.{{cite web | url=http://futureplanets.blogspot.com/2015/02/2016-budget-great-policy-document-and.html | title=2016 Budget: Great Policy Document and A Much Better Budget |first=Van |last=Kane | date=3 February 2015 | accessdate=8 February 2015}}{{cite news |last=Clark |first=Stephen |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/03/10/europa-clipper-concept-team-aims-for-launch-in-2022/ |title=Europa Multiple Flyby Mission concept team aims for launch in 2022 |work=Space Flight Now |date=March 10, 2015 |accessdate=2015-04-09 }} In April 2015, NASA offered to the European Space Agency to submit concepts for an additional probe to fly together with the ''Europa Clipper'' spacecraft, with a mass limit of 250 kg maximum.{{cite conference |last=Mauro Di Benedetto, Luigi Imperia, Daniele Durantea, Michele Dougherty, Luciano Iessa, Virginia |title=Augmenting NASA Europa Clipper by a small probe: Europa Tomography Probe (ETP) mission concept |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Mauro_Di_Benedetto/publication/309320752_Augmenting_NASA_Europa_Clipper_by_a_small_probe_Europa_Tomography_Probe_ETP_mission_concept/links/5809d58b08ae993dc05229e9.pdf |format=PDF |conference=67th International Astronautical Congress (IAC) |date=26–30 September 2016 }} It could be a simple probe, an impactor,[http://meetingorganizer.copernicus.org/EGU2016/EGU2016-16887.pdf Akon - A Penetrator for Europa]. (PDF) Geraint Jones. Geophysical Research Abstracts. Vol. 18, EGU2016-16887, 2016. EGU General Assembly 2016. or a lander.{{cite news |last=Clark |first=Stephen |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/04/10/nasa-invites-esa-to-build-europa-piggyback-probe/ |title=NASA invites ESA to build Europa piggyback probe |work=Space Flight Now |date=10 April 2015 |accessdate=2015-04-17 }} An internal assessment at ESA is underway to see if there is interest and funds available,{{cite news |last=Amos |first=Jonathan |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-36079069 |title=European scientists set eyes on ice moon Europa |work=BBC News |date=19 April 2016 |accessdate=2016-04-19 }}{{cite journal |title=The Europa initiative for ESA's cosmic vision: a potential European contribution to NASA’s Europa mission |journal=Geophysical Research Abstracts |year=2016 |last=Blanc |first=Michel |last2=Jones |first2=Geraint H. |last3=Prieto-Ballesteros |first3=Olga |last4=Sterken |first4=Veerle J. |volume=18 |url=http://meetingorganizer.copernicus.org/EGU2016/EGU2016-16378.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2016-09-29 }}[https://www.researchitaly.it/en/projects/joint-europa-mission-esa-and-nasa-together-towards-jupiter-icy-moon/ Joint Europa Mission: ESA and NASA together towards Jupiter icy moon]. Research Italy. 05/16/2017[http://meetingorganizer.copernicus.org/EGU2017/EGU2017-12931.pdf Joint Europa Mission (JEM): A multi-scale study of Europa to characterize its habitability and search for life.] (PDF) Michel Blanc, Olga Prieto Ballesteros, Nicolas Andre, and John F. Cooper. Geophysical Research Abstracts. Vol. 19, EGU2017-12931, 2017. EGU General Assembly 2017 opening a collaboration scheme similar to the very successful ''[[Cassini-Huygens]]'' approach. In May 2015, NASA chose nine instruments that would fly on board the orbiter. They will cost about $110 million over the next three years.{{cite news |last=Klotz |first=Irene |url=http://www.gazetteherald.com/nasas-europa-mission-will-look-for-lifes-ingredients-discovery-news/113901/ |title=NASA's Europa Mission Will Look for Life's Ingredients |work=Discovery News |date=26 May 2015 |accessdate=2015-05-26 }} In June 2015, NASA announced its approval of the mission concept, allowing the orbiter to move to its formulation stage,{{cite news |last=Howell |first=Elizabeth |url=http://www.space.com/29713-europa-mission-approved-for-development.html |title=NASA's Europa Mission Approved for Next Development Stage |work=Space.com |date=20 June 2015 |accessdate=2015-06-21 }} and in January 2016 it approved a lander as well.{{cite news |last=Kornfeld |first=Laurel |url=https://thespacereporter.com/2016/01/additional-1-3-billion-nasa-fund-next-mars-rover-europa-mission/ |title=Additional $1.3 billion for NASA to fund next Mrs rover, Europa mission |work=The Space Reported |date=4 January 2016 |accessdate=2016-01-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118071957/https://thespacereporter.com/2016/01/additional-1-3-billion-nasa-fund-next-mars-rover-europa-mission/ |archivedate=January 18, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} In May 2016 the [[Ocean Worlds Exploration Program]] was approved,[http://www.spacepolicyonline.com/pages/images/stories/NASA%20FY2017%20budget%20request%20Dec%2028%202016.pdf] (PDF) NASA'S FY2017 BUDGET REQUEST - Status at the End of the 114th Congress. December 28, 2016 of which the Europa mission is part.[https://spacepolicyonline.com/pages/images/stories/NASA%20FY2016%20budget%20request%20may%2027.pdf] (PDF) NASA'S FY2016 BUDGET REQUEST - Overview. May 27, 2015. In February 2017 the mission moved from Phase A to Phase B.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/nasas-europa-flyby-mission-moves-into-design-phase|title=NASA's Europa Flyby Mission Moves into Design Phase|last=Greicius|first=Tony|date=2017-02-21|newspaper=NASA|access-date=2017-02-22|language=en}} Phase B is the preliminary design phase of the mission, planned to continue through September 2018. In addition, subsystem vendors will be selected, as well as prototype hardware elements for the science instruments. Spacecraft subassemblies will be built and tested as well. Phases C and D include final design, spacecraft fabrication, assembly and testing, and launch. In 18 July 2017, the House Space Subcommittee held hearings on the ''Europa Clipper'' as a scheduled [[Large Strategic Science Missions]] class, and to discuss a possible follow up mission simply known as the [[Europa Lander (NASA)|Europa Lander]]. ==Objectives== [[Image:EuropaClipper.jpg|thumb|200px|The concept to achieve global-regional coverage of Europa during successive flybys.]] The goals of ''Europa Clipper'' are to explore Europa, investigate its [[Natural satellite habitability|habitability]] and aid in the selection of a landing site for the future [[Europa Lander (NASA)|Europa Lander]].{{cite journal |title=Science Potential from a Europa Lander |journal=Astrobiology | year=2013 |first=Robert T. |last=Pappalardo |first2=S. |last2=Vance |first3=F. |last3=Bagenal |first4=B.G. |last4=Bills |first5=D.L. |last5=Blaney |first6=D.D. |last6=Blankenship |first7=W.B. |last7=Brinckerhoff |first8=J.E.P. |last8=Connerney |volume=13 |issue=8 |pages=740–73 |doi=10.1089/ast.2013.1003 |pmid=23924246 |url=http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/pdfplus/10.1089/ast.2013.1003 |accessdate=2013-12-14 |last9=Hand |first9=K.P. |last10=Hoehler |first10=T.M. |last11=Leisner |first11=J.S. |last12=Kurth |first12=W.S. |last13=McGrath |first13=M.A. |last14=Mellon |first14=M.T. |last15=Moore |first15=J.M. |last16=Patterson |first16=G.W. |last17=Prockter |first17=L.M. |last18=Senske |first18=D.A. |last19=Schmidt |first19=B.E. |last20=Shock |first20=E.L. |last21=Smith |first21=D.E. |last22=Soderlund |first22=K.M. |bibcode=2013AsBio..13..740P }} This exploration is focused on understanding the three main requirements for life: liquid water, chemistry, and energy.[http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/7943832/?part=1 Europa mission update: Beyond payload selection]. Aerospace Conference, 2017 Specifically, the objectives are to study: *Ice shell and ocean: Confirm the existence, and characterize the nature, of water within or beneath the ice, and processes of surface-ice-ocean exchange. *Composition: Distribution and chemistry of key compounds and the links to ocean composition. *Geology: Characteristics and formation of surface features, including sites of recent or current activity. ===Strategy=== [[File:Europa Clipper orbit away from Jupiter radiation.jpg|thumb|left|A wide orbit of Jupiter with several flybys of Europa will minimize radiation exposure and increase data transfer speed]] Because Europa lies well within the harsh radiation fields surrounding Jupiter, even a radiation-hardened spacecraft in near orbit would be functional for just a few months.{{cite news |last=Kane |first=Van |url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/guest-blogs/van-kane/20140826-europa-how-less-can-be-more.html |title=Europa: How Less Can Be More |work=Planetary Society |date=26 August 2014 |accessdate=2014-08-29 }} Another key limiting factor on science for a Europa orbiter is not the time the instruments can make observations. Rather, it is the time available to return data to Earth. Most instruments can gather data far faster than the communications system can transmit it to Earth because there are a limited number of antennas available to receive the scientific data. Studies by scientists from the Jet Propulsion Laboratory show that by performing several flybys with many months to return data, the ''Europa Clipper'' concept will enable a $2B mission to conduct the most crucial measurements of the cancelled $4.3B [[Jupiter Europa Orbiter]] concept. Between each of the flybys, the spacecraft will have seven to ten days to transmit data stored during each brief encounter. That will let the spacecraft have up to a year of time to transmit its data compared to just 30 days for an orbiter. The result will be almost three times as much data returned to Earth, while reducing exposure to radiation. The ''Europa Clipper'' will not orbit Europa, but instead orbit [[Jupiter]] and conduct 45 [[Planetary flyby|flyby]]s of Europa at altitudes from {{convert|25|to|2700|km|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} each during its 3.5-year mission.{{cite journal |title=Europa Clipper Mission Concept: |journal=Eos, Transactions American Geophysical Union |date=20 May 2014 |last=Phillips |first=Cynthia B. |last2=Pappalardo |first2=Robert T. |volume=95 |issue=20 |pages=165–167 |doi=10.1002/2014EO200002 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2014EO200002/pdf |accessdate=2014-10-01 |bibcode=2014EOSTr..95..165P }}{{cite web |url=https://tools.wmflabs.org/makeref/ |title=Europa Clipper |work=NASA - JPL |date=2015 |accessdate=2015-02-08 }} A key feature of the mission concept is that the ''Clipper'' would use gravitational attraction from Europa, [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]] and [[Callisto (moon)|Callisto]] to change its trajectory, allowing the spacecraft to return to a different close approach point with each flyby.[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2014EO200002/pdf Europa Clipper Mission Concept: Exploring Jupiter's Ocean Moon] (PDF). Cynthis B. Phillips, and Robert T. Pappalardo. ''Eos, Transactions American Geophysical Union'', Volume 95, Issue 20. 20 May 2014. Each flyby would cover a different sector of Europa in order to achieve a medium-quality global topographic survey, including ice thickness.{{cite news |first=Van |last=Kane |title=Europa Clipper Update |date=26 May 2013 |url=http://futureplanets.blogspot.com/2013/05/europa-clipper-update.html |work=Future Planetary Exploration }} The ''Europa Clipper'' could conceivably flyby at low altitude through the plumes of water vapor erupting from the moon's icy crust, thus sampling its subsurface ocean without having to land on the surface and drill though the ice. The ''Europa Clipper'' will inherit tested technology of the [[Galileo (spacecraft)|''Galileo'']] and [[Juno (spacecraft)|''Juno'']] Jupiter orbiters with regards to radiation protection. Shielding will be provided by 150 kilograms of [[titanium]]. To maximize its effectiveness, the electronics will be nested in the core of the spacecraft for additional radiation protection. {{clear}} ==Design and construction== ===Power=== Both [[radioisotope thermoelectric generator]] and [[photovoltaics|photovoltaic]] power sources were assessed to power the orbiter.A. Eremenko ''et al.'', "Europa Clipper spacecraft configuration evolution," ''2014 IEEE Aerospace Conference'', pp. 1–13, Big Sky, MT, March 1–8, 2014 Although solar power is only 4% as intense at Jupiter as it is in Earth's orbit, powering a Jupiter orbital spacecraft by [[Solar panels on spacecraft|solar panels]] was demonstrated by the [[Juno (spacecraft)|Juno Mission]]. The alternative to solar panels was a [[Multi-Mission Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator]], fueled with [[plutonium-238]]. The power source has already been demonstrated in the [[Mars Science Laboratory]] mission. Five units were available, with one reserved for the [[Mars 2020 rover mission]] and another as backup. In September 2013 it was decided that the solar array was the less expensive option to power the spacecraft, and on October 3, 2014, it was announced that solar panels were chosen to power ''Europa Clipper''. The mission's designers determined that solar was both cheaper than plutonium and practical to use on the spacecraft. Despite the increased weight of solar panels compared to plutonium-powered generators, the vehicle's mass had been projected to still be within acceptable launch limits.{{cite web | url=http://spacenews.com/42121europa-clipper-opts-for-solar-power-over-nuclear/ | title=Europa Clipper Opts for Solar Power over Nuclear | first=Jeff | last=Foust | date=8 October 2014 | accessdate=8 February 2015}} Initial analysis suggest that each panel will have a surface area of {{convert|18|sqm|sqft|abbr=on}} and produce 150 watts continuously when pointed towards the Sun while orbiting Jupiter.{{cite news |first=Casey |last=Dreier | title=NASA's Europa Mission Concept Rejects ASRGs – May Use Solar Panels at Jupiter Instead |date=5 September 2013 |url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2013/20130905-no-asrgs-for-europa.html |work=The Planetary Society }} While in Europa's shadow, batteries will enable the spacecraft to continue gathering data. However, [[ionizing radiation]] can damage solar panels. The ''Europa Clipper''{{'s}} orbit will pass through Jupiter's intense magnetosphere, which is expected to gradually degrade the solar panels as the mission progresses. The solar panels will be provided by Airbus Defense and Space Netherlands.{{cite newsletter |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/system/internal_resources/details/original/116_Europa-Clipper-Newsletter-External-vol2issue1_FINAL.pdf |title=Spacecraft Highlights |work=The Sextant – Europa Clipper Newsletter |publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |volume=2 |issue=1 |page=3 |date=March 2018 |access-date=20 September 2018}} ===Scientific payload=== The ''Europa Clipper'' mission is equipped with a sophisticated suite of 9 instruments to study Europa's interior and ocean, geology, chemistry, and habitability. The spacecraft payload and trajectory are subject to change as the mission design matures.{{cite conference |last=Amato |first=Michael J. |last2=Spidaliere |first2=P. |last3=Mahaffy |first3=P. |authorlink3=et al |title=Biosignature Explorer for Europa (BEE) Probe – The Concept for Directly Searching for Life Evidence on Europa at Lower Cost and Risk |url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2602.pdf |format=PDF |conference=47th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference |year=2016 }} The nine science instruments for the orbiter, announced in May 2015, have an estimated total mass of {{convert|82|kg|abbr=on}} and are listed below:{{cite news |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4598 |title=NASA's Europa Mission Begins with Selection of Science Instruments |work=Jet Propulsion Laboratory |publisher=NASA News |date=26 May 2015 |accessdate=2015-05-27 }} {| class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col" style="width:135px;"| Instrument name ! scope="col" style="width:50px;" | Abbr. ! scope="col" | Description and scientific objectives |- | style="text-align:center;" | [[Europa Thermal Emission Imaging System]] | style="text-align:center;" | E-THEMIS |The [[Europa Thermal Emission Imaging System]] will provide high spatial resolution, multi-spectral imaging of Europa in the [[Infrared|mid infrared]] and [[far infrared]] bands to help detect active sites, such as potential vents erupting plumes of water into space. This instrument is derived from the Thermal Emission Imaging System ([[Thermal Emission Imaging System|THEMIS]]) on the ''[[2001 Mars Odyssey]]'' orbiter, also developed by Philip Christensen. *{{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Phillipp Christensen, [[Arizona State University]]}} |- | style="text-align:center;" | [[Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa]] | style="text-align:center;" | MISE |The [[Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa]] is an imaging [[Infrared spectroscopy|near infrared spectrometer]] to probe the surface composition of Europa, identifying and mapping the distributions of [[organic compound|organics]] (including [[amino acid]]s and [[tholin]]s[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017AAS...22913804W MISE: A Search for Organics on Europa]. Whalen, Kelly; Lunine, Jonathan I.; Blaney, Diana L. ''American Astronomical Society'', AAS Meeting #229, id.138.04. January 2017.{{cite news |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4602 |title=Europa Mission to Probe Magnetic Field and Chemistry |work=Jet Propulsion Laboratory |date=27 May 2015 |accessdate=2017-10-23}}), salts, acid hydrates, water ice phases, and other materials. From these measurements, scientists expect to be able to relate the moon's surface composition to the habitability of its ocean.{{cite news |last=Blaney |first=Diana L. |title=Europa Composition Using Visible to Short Wavelength Infrared Spectroscopy |work=JPL |publisher=American Astronomical Society, DPS meeting #42, #26.04; Bulletin of the American Astronomical Society, Vol. 42, p.1025 |date=2010 }} MISE is built in collaboration with the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (APL). *{{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Diana Blaney, [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]}} |- | style="text-align:center;" | [[Europa Imaging System]] | style="text-align:center;" | EIS | The [[Europa Imaging System]] is a visible-spectrum wide and narrow angle camera instrument that will map most of Europa at {{convert|50|m|abbr=on}} resolution, and will provide images of selected surface areas at up to 0.5 m resolution. *{{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Elizabeth Turtle, [[Applied Physics Laboratory]]}} |- | style="text-align:center;" | [[Europa Ultraviolet Spectrograph]] | style="text-align:center;" | Europa - UVS | The [[Europa Ultraviolet Spectrograph]] instrument will be able to detect small plumes and will provide valuable data about the composition and dynamics of the moon's exosphere. Principal Investigator Kurt Retherford was part of a group that discovered plumes erupting from Europa while using the Hubble Space Telescope in the UV spectrum.{{cite journal| last=Roth| first=Lorenz| year=2014| title=Transient Water Vapor at Europa’s South Pole| journal=Science| volume=343| issue=171| pages=171–4| doi=10.1126/science.1247051| issn=1095-9203| pmid=24336567| bibcode=2014Sci...343..171R}}| accessdate=2015-05-27 *{{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Kurt Retherford, [[Southwest Research Institute]]}} |- | style="text-align:center;" | [[Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface]] | style="text-align:center;" | REASON | The [[Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface]] ([[Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface|REASON]]){{cite news |url=http://astrobiology.com/2015/06/radar-techniques-used-in-antarctica-will-scour-europa-for-life-supporting-environments.html |title=Radar Techniques Used in Antarctica Will Scour Europa for Life-Supporting Environments |work=University of Texas Austin |date=1 June 2015 |accessdate=2015-06-04 }}{{cite journal|last=Grima|first=Cyril|last2=Schroeder|first2=Dustin|last3=Blakenship|first3=Donald D.|last4=Young|first4=Duncan A.|date=15 November 2014|title=Planetary landing-zone reconnaissance using ice-penetrating radar data: Concept validation in Antarctica|journal=Planetary and Space Science|volume=103|pages=191–204|bibcode=2014P&SS..103..191G|doi=10.1016/j.pss.2014.07.018}} is a dual-frequency [[Radioglaciology|ice penetrating radar]] instrument that is designed to characterize and sound Europa's ice crust from the near-surface to the ocean, revealing the hidden structure of Europa's ice shell and potential water pockets within. This instrument will be built by JPL. *{{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Donald Blankenship, [[University of Texas at Austin|University of Texas]]}} |- | style="text-align:center;" | [[Interior Characterization of Europa using Magnetometry]] | style="text-align:center;" | ICEMAG | The [[Interior Characterization of Europa using Magnetometry]] (ICEMAG) is a [[magnetometer]] that will measure the magnetic field near Europa and in conjunction with the [[Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding|PIMS]] instrument will probe the location, depth, thickness and salinity of Europa's subsurface ocean using multi-frequency electromagnetic sounding. *{{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Carol Raymond, [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]}} |- | style="text-align:center;" | [[Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding]] | style="text-align:center;" | PIMS | The [[Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding]] measures the [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] surrounding Europa to characterise the magnetic fields generated by plasma currents. These plasma currents mask the [[Electromagnetic induction|magnetic induction]] response of Europa's subsurface ocean. In conjunction with the ICEMAG instrument, it is key to determining Europa's ice shell thickness, ocean depth, and salinity. PIMS will also probe the mechanisms responsible for weathering and releasing material from Europa's surface into the atmosphere and ionosphere and understanding how Europa influences its local space environment and Jupiter's magnetosphere.{{cite web |url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/icyworlds2014/pdf/4032.pdf |format=PDF |title=Workshop on the Habitability of Icy Worlds (2014) |last=Westlake |first=Joseph |date=2014 |accessdate=2015-05-27 }}{{Cite journal|last=Joseph|first=Westlake,|date=2015-12-14|title=The Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS): Enabling Required Plasma Measurements for the Exploration of Europa| url=https://agu.confex.com/agu/fm15/webprogram/Paper66117.html|language=English|publisher=Agu}} *{{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Joseph Westlake, [[Applied Physics Laboratory]]}} |- | style="text-align:center;" | [[Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration]] | style="text-align:center;" | MASPEX | The [[Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration]] will determine the composition of the surface and subsurface ocean by measuring Europa's extremely tenuous atmosphere and any surface materials ejected into space. Jack Waite, who led development of MASPEX, was also Science Team Lead of the Ion and Neutral Mass Spectrometer (INMS) on ''[[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]]'' spacecraft. *{{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Jack Waite, [[Southwest Research Institute]]}} |- | style="text-align:center;" | [[Surface Dust Analyser|SUrface Dust Mass Analyzer]] | style="text-align:center;" | SUDA | The [[Surface Dust Analyser|SUrface Dust Mass Analyzer]] is a [[Mass spectrometry|mass spectrometer]] that will measure the composition of small solid particles ejected from Europa, providing the opportunity to directly sample the surface and potential plumes on low-altitude flybys. The instrument is capable of identifying traces of organic and inorganic compounds in the ice of ejecta.{{cite journal |title=Linear high resolution dust mass spectrometer for a mission to the Galilean satellites |journal=Planetary and Space Science |date=May 2012 |last=Kempf |first=Sascha |volume=65 |issue=1 |pages=10–20 |doi=10.1016/j.pss.2011.12.019 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0032063311003928 |accessdate=2015-05-27 |display-authors=etal |bibcode=2012P&SS...65...10K}} *{{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Sascha Kempf, [[University of Colorado Boulder]]}} |} ===Possible secondary elements=== The ''Europa Clipper'' mission considers an extra mass of about 250 kg to carry an additional flight element. About a dozen proposals have been suggested, a few of which are described next: ;Nanosatellites [[File:CubeSat in hand.jpg|thumb|1U [[CubeSat]] is a 10 cm (4 in) cube]] Since the ''Europa Clipper'' mission may not be able to easily modify its orbital trajectory or altitude to fly through the episodic water [[Europa (moon)#Plumes|plumes]], scientists and engineers working on the mission have investigated deploying from the spacecraft several [[miniaturized satellite]]s of the [[CubeSat]] format, possibly driven by [[ion thruster]]s, to fly through the plumes and assess the habitability of Europa's internal ocean.{{cite news |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4330 |title=JPL Selects Europa CubeSat Proposals for Study |work=Jet Propulsion Laboratory |publisher=NASA |date=8 October 2014 |accessdate=2015-04-17 }} Some early proposals include ''Mini-MAGGIE'',[http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/1928.pdf Mini-MAGGIE: CubeSat MAGnetism and Gravity Investigation at Europa.] (PDF) 2016. ''DARCSIDE'',[http://digitalcommons.usu.edu/smallsat/2016/S1BeyondLEO/4/ CubeSat Session I: Beyond LEO]. 2016.[http://www.jossonline.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Final-Thelen-A-Europa-CubeSat-Concept-Study-for-Measuring-Atmospheric-Density-and-Heavy-Ion-Flux.pdf A Europa CubeSat Concept Study for Measuring Atmospheric Density and Heavy Ion Flux]. Thelen, A. et al. (2017): ''Journal of Small Satellites'', Vol. 6, No. 2, pp. 591–607 and ''Sylph''.[http://digitalcommons.usu.edu/smallsat/2016/TS11SciPayload1/6/ Sylph – A SmallSat Probe Concept Engineered to Answer Europa's Big Question]. 2016. The ''Europa Clipper'' would relay signals from the nanosatellites back to Earth. With propulsion, some nanosatellites could also be capable of entering orbit around Europa. ;Secondary orbiters ;*''Biosignature Explorer for Europa'' :NASA is also assessing the release of an additional {{convert|250|kg|abbr=on}} probe called ''Biosignature Explorer for Europa'' (BEE), that would be equipped with a basic bi-propellant engine and cold gas thrusters to be more agile and responsive to the episodic activity on Europa and sample and analyze the water plumes for [[biosignature]]s and life evidence before they are destroyed by radiation. The BEE plume probe would be equipped with a proven [[mass spectrometer]] combined with [[gas chromatograph]] separation. It would also carry a UV plume targeting camera as well as visible and [[Infrared camera|IR cameras]] to image the active region with better resolution than the ''Clipper'' mother ship instruments. The BEE probe would fly through at 2–10 km altitude, then make a quick exit and perform its analysis far from the radiation belts. ;*''Europa Tomography Probe'' (ETP) :A European proposal is an independent powered spacecraft equipped with a [[magnetometer]] that would orbit Europa on a polar orbit for at least six months. It would determine the deep interior structure of Europa and provide a good determination of the ice shell thickness and ocean depth, which arguably cannot be done accurately by multiple flybys. ;Impactor probes :Some proposed impactor probe concepts include those by the Netherlands,[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11038-017-9508-7 An Impacting Descent Probe for Europa and the Other Galilean Moons of Jupiter]. Wurz, P., Lasi, D., Thomas, N. et al. ''Earth Moon Planets'' (2017) 120: 113. {{doi|10.1007/s11038-017-9508-7}} and United Kingdom.[https://research-information.bristol.ac.uk/files/70486876/Europa.pdf Europa's small impactor flux and seismic detection predictions]. Tsu ji, D., & Teanby, N. A. (2016). ''Icarus'', 277, 39-55. {{doi|10.1016/j.icarus.2016.04.036}} ;Flyby sample return The ''Europa Life Signature Assayer'' (ELSA) concept by the University of Colorado consists of a probe that is flown as a secondary payload. ELSA would use a small impactor to create a plume of subsurface particles and catapult them to altitudes where it would be able to pass through to collect samples and analyze them on board.[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20170002063.pdf TRAJECTORY AND NAVIGATION DESIGN FOR AN IMPACTOR MISSION CONCEPT] (PDF). Andres Dono Perez, Roland Burtony, Jan Stuplz, and David Mauro. (2017) NASA AAS 17-487.[https://www.colorado.edu/aerospace/sites/default/files/attached-files/elsa_aiaa.pdf Project ELSA: Europa Lander for Science Acquisition]. Darren Combs, Gabe Frank, Sara Grandone, Colton Hall, Daniel Johnson, Trevor Luke, Scott Mende, Daniel Nowicki, Ben Stringer. University of Colorado, Boulder. 2017. A variation of this concept is the 1996 ''Ice Clipper'', which involves a 10 kg impactor that would be jettisoned from the main spacecraft to impact Europa, thereby creating a debris cloud in nearby space about 100 km altitude, subsequently sampled by a small spacecraft on a close flyby and use Europa's gravitational force for a free return trajectory.[http://drewryanjones.com/assets/conf_paper_2016_no3.pdf Trajectories for Europa Flyby Sample Return] (PDF). Drew Ryan Jones, JPL."Planetary Protection for a Europa Surface Sample Return: The Ice Clipper Mission". Chris McKay, ''Advances in Space Research'', Vol. 30, No. 6, 2002, pp. 1601-1605."Europa Ice Clipper: A Discovery class sample return mission to Europa." Chris McKay et al. Proposal from NASA Ames Research Center to NASA HQ submitted 11 Dec 1996. The collection mechanism is tentatively considered to be [[Aerogel]] (similar to [[Stardust (spacecraft)|''Stardust'' mission]]). ===Add-on lander history === An early ''Europa Clipper'' concept called for including a stationary lander about 1 meter in diameter, perhaps about {{convert|230|kg|abbr=on}} with a maximum of {{convert|30|kg|abbr=on}} for instruments plus propellant. Suggested instruments were a [[mass spectrometer]] and a [[Raman spectrometer]] to determine the chemistry of the surface. The lander was proposed to be delivered to Europa by the main spacecraft and possibly require the [[Mars Science Laboratory#Sky crane|sky crane system]] for a high precision, soft landing near an active crevasse.{{cite news |last=Berger |first=Eric |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/11/attempt-no-landing-there-yeah-right-were-going-to-europa/ |title=Attempt no landing there? Yeah right—we’re going to Europa |work=ARS Technica |date=17 November 2015 |pages=1–3 |accessdate=2016-01-05 }} The lander would operate about 10 days on the surface using battery power. In January 2016 it was determined that including the additional mass of a lander and detachable probes, meant the ''Europa Clipper'' may need be launched with NASA's [[Space Launch System]] (SLS) [[heavy lift launch vehicle]] that could arrive at Jupiter on a direct trajectory in less than three years. The ''Europa Clipper'' would take about three years to image 95% of the surface of Europa at about 50 meters per pixel. With this data, scientists could then find a suitable landing site. By one estimate, including a lander could add as much as $1 billion to the mission's cost. ;Separate launch [[File:PIA21048 - Europa Lander Mission Concept (Artist's Rendering).jpg|thumb|Artist's impression of the separately launched Europa lander mission (2017 design)]] It was determined that designing a system capable of landing on a surface about which very little is known, is too much risk, and that the ''Europa Clipper'' will lay the foundation for a future landing mission by performing detailed reconnaissance first.[https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-receives-science-report-on-europa-lander-concept NASA Receives Science Report on Europa Lander Concept]. NASA TV. 8 February 2017. This led to a stand-alone mission proposal in 2017: the [[Europa Lander (NASA)|Europa Lander]].[http://spacenews.com/jpl-moves-ahead-with-mars-and-europa-missions-despite-funding-uncertainty/ JPL moves ahead with Mars and Europa missions despite funding uncertainty]. Jeff Foust. July 18, 2017. The NASA Europa Lander, if funded, would be launched separately in 2024 to complement the studies by the ''Europa Clipper'' mission.{{Cite web|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=6737|title=NASA Receives Science Report on Europa Lander Concept|website=NASA/JPL|access-date=2017-02-15}}[http://spacenews.com/nasa-weighing-dual-launches-of-europa-orbiter-and-lander/ NASA weighing dual launches of Europa orbiter and lander.] Joe Faust, ''Space News''. February 2016. If funded, approximately 10 proposals may be selected to proceed into a competitive process with a $1.5 million budget per investigation.[https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-asks-scientific-community-to-think-on-possible-europa-lander-instruments NASA Asks Scientific Community to Think on Possible Europa Lander Instruments]. NASA News. 17 May 2017. == Launch and trajectory== In the baseline mission profile, ''Europa Clipper'' is planned to be carried aboard NASA's [[Space Launch System]] (SLS) [[heavy-lift launch vehicle]], on a direct trajectory to Jupiter in less than three years. {{As of|September 2018}}, departure is scheduled for 2023. Since the development and readiness of the SLS may not match the mission's timing, an alternative trajectory profile would use a commercial rocket such as [[Delta IV Heavy]] or [[Falcon Heavy]], with a longer 6-year cruise time involving [[gravity assist]] maneuvers at Venus, Earth and Earth again. Launch windows are available from 2022 to 2025. == See also == {{Portal|Astrobiology}} *[[Europa Jupiter System Mission – Laplace]], cancelled in 2011 *[[Europa Orbiter]], cancelled in 2002 *[[Exploration of Jupiter]] *[[Jupiter Icy Moon Explorer]], ESA orbiter for Jupiter's big moons *[[Laplace-P]], a proposed Jupiter orbiter and Ganymede lander == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Commons category|Europa Multiple-Flyby Mission}} * {{Official website|http://www.nasa.gov/europa}} * [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/missions/europaflyby ''Europa'' Mission] at [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/ NASA's Solar System Exploration] {{Europa Clipper}} {{Europa}} {{Jupiter}} {{Planetary Missions Program Office|Solar System Exploration=y}} {{Jupiter spacecraft}} {{NASA space program}} {{Astrobiology}} {{Extraterrestrial life}} {{Future spaceflights}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Europa Clipper}} [[Category:Proposed NASA space probes]] [[Category:Proposed astrobiology space missions]] [[Category:NASA programs]] [[Category:2025 in spaceflight]] [[Category:Missions to Jupiter]] [[Category:Orbiters (space probe)]] [[Category:Europa (moon)]] [[Category:Solar System Exploration program]] [[Category:Europa Clipper| ]]

{{for|the journal|Evidence Based Library and Information Practice (journal)}} '''Evidence-based library and information practice''' (EBLIP) or '''evidence-based librarianship''' (EBL) is the application of the interdisciplinary approach known as [[evidence-based practice]] (EBP) to problems in the field of [[library and information science]] (LIS). This means that all practical decisions made within LIS should 1) be based on research studies and 2) that these research studies are selected and interpreted according to some specific norms characteristic for EBP. Typically such norms disregard theoretical studies and qualitative studies and consider quantitative studies according to a narrow set of criteria of what counts as evidence. If such a narrow set of methodological criteria are not applied, it is better instead to speak of ''research based library and information practice.'' <ref name="HjorlandBirger">Hjørland, Birger (2011). Evidence based practice: An analysis based on the philosophy of science. ''Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology'', 62(7), 1301–1310.</ref>
== Characteristics == Evidence-based practice in general has been characterised as a [[Positivism|positivist]] approach;<ref name="HjorlandBirger" /> EBLIP is therefore also a positivist approach to LIS.<ref>Hjørland, B. (2005). Empiricism, rationalism and positivism in library and information science. Journal of Documentation, 61(1), 130-155.</ref> As such, EBLIP is an approach in contrast to other approaches to LIS. The use of statistical approaches known as [[meta-analysis]] to conclude what evidence has been reported in the literature is one among other methods which is typical for the evidence-based approach.
In 2002, Booth noted the three schools of EBILP had some commonalities, including the context of day-to-day decision-making, an emphasis on improving the quality of professional practice, a pragmatic focus on the 'best available evidence', incorporation of the user perspective, the acceptance of a broad range of quantitative and qualitative [[research design]]s, and access, either first-hand or second-hand, to the (process of) evidence-based practice and its products. He added one more, that EBILP is concerned with getting the best value for money.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Booth |first1=Andrew |title=From EBM to EBL: Two Steps Forward or One Step Back? |journal=Medical Reference Services Quarterly |date=March 2002 |volume=21 |issue=3 |pages=51–64 |doi=10.1300/J115v21n03_04}}</ref>
==The role of library and information science in EBP== Evidence-based practice in general is based on a very thorough search of the scientific literature and a very thorough selection and analysis of the retrieved literature. A close familiarity with database searching is needed, and library and information professionals have important roles to play in this respect. Therefore LIS professionals should be well suited to help professionals in other disciplines doing EBP. EBLIP is the application of this approach on LIS itself. It should be mentioned, however, that EBP started in medicine as evidence-based medicine (EBM) from which it spread to other fields. Only slowly and to a limited extent has EBP moved on to LIS. The EBLIP process can be applied to a variety of scenarios in LIS, including customer service,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Abbott|first1=Wendy|title=Persuasive Evidence: Improving Customer Service through Evidence Based Librarianship|journal=Evidence based library and information practice|date=2006|volume=1|issue=1|pages=58–68|url=http://epublications.bond.edu.au/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1002&context=library_pubs}}</ref> [[collection development]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Eldredge|first1=Jonathan|title=Evidence‐based librarianship: The EBL process|journal=Evidence‐based librarianship|date=2006|volume=24|issue=3|pages=341–354}}</ref> [[library management]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Greenwood|first1=Helen|last2=Cleeve|first2=Marigold|title=Embracing change: evidence‐based management in action|journal=Library Management|date=2008|volume=29|issue=3|pages=173–184|doi=10.1108/01435120810855304}}</ref> and [[information literacy]] instruction.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gross|first1=Melissa|last2=Latham|first2=Don|last3=Armstrong|first3=Bonnie|title=Improving below-proficient information literacy skills: designing an evidence-based educational intervention|journal=College Teaching|date=2012|volume=60|issue=3|pages=104–111}}</ref> In general, quantitative methods are used in LIS research.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=VanScoy |first1=Amy |last2=Fontana |first2=Cady |title=How reference and information service is studied: Research approaches and methods |journal=Library & Information Science Research |date=April 2016 |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=94–100 |doi=10.1016/j.lisr.2016.04.002}}</ref>
A 2010 study revealed that professionals experienced evidence-based practice as variously: not relevant; learning from published research; service improvement; a way of being and as a weapon.<ref>https://eprints.qut.edu.au/32798/1/PIL_21_Ch13_201004.pdf</ref>

{{Use Australian English|date=April 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} [[File:Route of the Far Eastern party.png|thumb|upright=2|The route of the Far Eastern Party, from the Main Base at [[Cape Denison]] in the north-west, across the Mertz and [[Ninnis Glacier]]s, and return. {{legend|blue|Mawson, Mertz and Ninnis, 10 November – 14 December 1912}}{{legend|red|Mawson and Mertz, 14 December 1912 – 8 January 1913}}{{legend|green|Mawson alone, 8 January – 8 February 1913}}]]
The '''Far Eastern Party''' was a sledging component of the 1911–14 [[Australasian Antarctic Expedition]], which investigated the previously unexplored coastal regions of Antarctica west of [[Cape Adare]]. Led by expedition commander [[Douglas Mawson]], the party aimed to explore the area far to the east of their main base in [[Adélie Land]], pushing about {{convert|500|mi}} towards [[Victoria Land]]. Accompanying Mawson were [[Belgrave Edward Sutton Ninnis]], a lieutenant in the [[Royal Fusiliers]], and the Swiss ski expert [[Xavier Mertz]]; the party used [[sledge dog]]s to increase their speed across the ice. Initially they made good progress, crossing two huge glaciers on their route south-east.
On 14 December 1912, with the party more than {{convert|311|mi}} from the safety of the main base at [[Cape Denison]], Ninnis and the sledge he was walking beside broke through the snow lid of a [[crevasse]] and were lost. Their supplies now severely compromised, Mawson and Mertz turned back west, gradually shooting the remaining sledge dogs for food to supplement their scarce rations. As they crossed the first glacier on their return journey Mertz became sick, making progress difficult. After almost a week of making very little headway Mertz died, leaving Mawson to carry on alone.
For almost a month he pulled his sledge across the Antarctic, crossing the second glacier, despite an illness that increasingly weakened him. Mawson reached the comparative safety of Aladdin's Cave—a food depot {{convert|5.5|mi}} from the main base—on 1 February 1913, only to be trapped there for a week while a [[blizzard]] raged outside. As a result, he missed the ship back to Australia; the [[SY Aurora|SY ''Aurora'']] had sailed on 8 February, just hours before his return to Cape Denison, after waiting for more than three weeks. With a relief party, Mawson remained at Cape Denison until the ''Aurora'' returned the following summer in December 1913.
The causes of Mertz's death and Mawson's related illness remain uncertain; a 1969 study suggested [[hypervitaminosis A]], presumably caused by the men eating the livers of their [[Greenland Dog|Greenland Huskies]], which are now known to be unusually high in [[vitamin A]]. While this is considered the most likely theory, dissenting opinions suggest prolonged cold exposure or psychological stresses. In 1976 explorer and mountaineer [[Edmund Hillary|Sir Edmund Hillary]] described Mawson's month-long journey as "probably the greatest story of lone survival in Polar exploration".<ref name="Bickel p. x">Edmund Hillary (1976) in Bickel (2000), p. ''x''</ref>
== Background == [[File:Final photograph of the Far Eastern party.jpg|thumb|The last photograph taken of the Far Eastern Party, by [[Archibald Lang McLean]] of the Eastern Coastal Party, after the parties separated on 17 November 1912]]
The [[Australasian Antarctic Expedition]], commanded by [[Douglas Mawson]], explored part of [[East Antarctica]] between 1911 and 1914. The expedition's main base was established in January 1912 at [[Cape Denison]] in [[Commonwealth Bay]], [[Adélie Land]].<ref name="Ayres p. 63">Ayres (1999), p. 63</ref> This was much farther west than originally intended; dense [[Drift ice|pack ice]] had prevented the expedition ship [[SY Aurora|SY ''Aurora'']] from landing closer to [[Cape Adare]], the original eastern limit.<ref name="Bickel p. 43">Bickel (2000), p. 43</ref> Only after the ''Aurora''—heading west—had rounded the ice tongue of the [[Mertz Glacier]]{{refn|For simplicity, this article refers to the Mertz and [[Ninnis Glacier]]s by the names given to them following the expedition. During the expedition itself they remained unnamed.|group="nb"}} was a landing made.<ref name="Ayres p. 63"/>
Battling [[katabatic wind]]s that swept down from the [[Antarctic Plateau]], the shore party erected their hut and began preparations for the following summer's sledging expeditions.<ref name="Ayres p. 63"/> The men readied clothing, sledges, tents and rations,{{refn|The men's sledging rations consisted mainly of [[pemmican]] and [[plasmon biscuit]]s, which could be ground, mixed with water and boiled to make a stew or soup known as [[hoosh]]. Added to the rations were basics such as butter, chocolate and tea; the daily ration was set at around {{convert|34|oz}} per man.<ref name="Riffenburgh pp. 88-89">Riffenburgh (2009), pp. 88–89</ref>|group="nb"}} conducted limited survey parties, and deployed several caches of supplies.<ref name="Ayres p. 67">Ayres (1999), p. 67</ref><ref name="Riffenburgh p. 87">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 87</ref> The most notable of these depots was Aladdin's Cave, excavated from the ice on the slope {{convert|5.5|mi}} to the south of the main hut.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 90">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 90</ref>
On 27 October 1912 Mawson outlined the summer sledging program.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 98">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 98</ref> Of the seven sledging parties that would depart from Cape Denison, three would head east. The Eastern Coastal Party, led by the geologist [[Cecil Madigan]], was charged with exploring beyond the Mertz Glacier tongue;<ref name="Mawson p. 135">Mawson (1996), p. 135</ref> they would initially be supported by the Near Eastern Party led by [[Frank Leslie Stillwell|Frank Stillwell]], which would then turn to mapping the area between Cape Denison and the glacier.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 99">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 99</ref>
The final party, led by Mawson, would push rapidly inland to the south of the Coastal Party towards [[Victoria Land]], an area he had explored during [[Ernest Shackleton]]'s [[Nimrod Expedition|British Antarctic Expedition]] in 1908–09. He hoped to travel about {{convert|500|mi}} east, collecting geological data and specimens, mapping the coast, and claiming territory for the crown.<ref name="Bickel pp. 78-79">Bickel (2000), pp. 78–79</ref>
Assisting him on this Far Eastern Party would be [[Belgrave Edward Sutton Ninnis]], a lieutenant in the [[Royal Fusiliers]], and the Swiss ski expert [[Xavier Mertz]].<ref name="Bickel pp. 78-79"/><ref name="Riffenburgh p. 42">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 42</ref> They were in charge of the expedition's [[sledge dogs]]—[[Greenland Dog|Greenland Huskies]]—who would be crucial if the party was to cover the distance at the speed Mawson intended. Ninnis and Mertz had spent the winter preparing the dogs for the journey, sewing harnesses and teaching them to run in teams with the sledges.{{refn|There was division as to which method of securing the dogs to the sledge was best; Mawson favoured the [[Yukon]] method, whereby the dogs were arranged in pairs, attached to a single line, with a man pulling in front, while Ninnis and Mertz preferred the [[Eskimo]] method, where the dogs were arranged in a fan-shape. Ninnis recorded that Mawson was concerned that in [[crevasse]]d country the Eskimo method would mean "the whole show—sledges, dogs and men—would be more likely to go down [into a crevasse] together, whereas by the [Yukon] method only the man would go, and could be hoicked out again." While Ninnis continued to express his reservations about the Yukon method—chiefly that the lines easily became tangled and the long line put the farthest dogs out of range of the whip—by late October Mawson had settled on the technique, and Ninnis and Mertz devoted their time to accustoming the dogs.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 107">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 107</ref>|group="nb"}}<ref name="Bickel p. 67">Bickel (2000), p. 67</ref><ref name="Bickel p. 77">Bickel (2000), p. 77</ref> Each of the parties was required to return to Cape Denison by 15 January 1913, to allow time for the ''Aurora'' to collect them and escape Antarctic waters unencumbered by the winter sea ice.<ref name="Bickel p. 81">Bickel (2000), p. 81</ref>
== Journey eastwards == [[File:Douglas Mawson resting.jpg|thumb|upright=1|Mawson rests on one of the sledges at Aladdin's Cave during the outward journey]] Blizzards prevented the parties from leaving Cape Denison until 10 November 1912, four days after the scheduled start date. In his diary, Mertz recorded the clearing weather as "definitely a good omen".<ref name="Ayres p. 70">Ayres (1999), p. 70</ref> Mawson wrote a short letter to his fiancée, Paquita Delprat:
{{quote|The weather is fine this morning though the wind still blows. We shall get away in an hour's time. I have two good companions, Dr Mertz and Lieut. Ninnis. It is unlikely that any harm will happen to us, but should I not return to you in Australia, please know that I truly loved you. I must be closing now as the others are waiting.<ref name="Ayres p. 70"/>}}
Allowing Madigan and Stillwell's parties a head-start, Mawson, Ninnis, Mertz and the seventeen dogs left Cape Denison early in the afternoon, reaching Aladdin's Cave four hours later.<ref name="Bickel pp. 86-87">Bickel (2000), pp. 86–87</ref><ref name="Riffenburgh p. 103">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 103</ref> Stopping for the night, they took on extra supplies and rearranged the sledges. The first team of dogs would haul a train of two sledges, which collectively carried half the weight of the party's supplies. The remaining supplies were put on the third sledge, towed by the second dog team.{{refn|Mawson calculated the weight of the supplies (including sledges) at {{convert|1723|lb}}, of which food (for humans and dogs) and fuel made up {{convert|1260|lb}}.<ref name="Bickel p. 87">Bickel (2000), p. 87</ref>|group="nb"}}<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 103"/>
Heading south the following day to avoid [[crevasse]]s to the east, they travelled about {{convert|8|mi}} before poor weather forced them to stop and camp. Strong winds confined them to the tent until 13 November, and they were able to travel just a short distance before the weather picked up again. For three more days they remained in their tent, unable even to light the stove.<ref name="Bickel pp. 90-91">Bickel (2000), pp. 90–91</ref> When the weather cleared on 16 November, Madigan and Stillwell's parties joined them.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 105">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 105</ref> The three parties travelled together for much of the following day, before Mawson's party separated and pushed on ahead in the late afternoon.<ref name="Bickel p. 92">Bickel (2000), p. 92</ref>
=== Mertz and Ninnis Glaciers === Heading south-east towards the Mertz Glacier, with Mertz skiing ahead and Mawson and Ninnis driving the dogs, the party covered {{convert|15|mi}} on 18 November.<ref name="Riffenburgh pp. 106-107">Riffenburgh (2009), pp. 106–107</ref> This was despite encountering [[sastrugi]]—ridges in the ice caused by wind—as high as {{convert|3|ft|cm}}, that caused the dogs to slip and the sledges to roll.<ref name="Bickel p. 96">Bickel (2000), p. 96</ref><ref name="Mawson p. 132">Mawson (1988), p. 132</ref> During the day they passed two peaks, which Mawson named [[Madigan Nunatak]] and [[Aurora Peak]], after the leader of the Eastern Coastal Party and the expedition's ship.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 106">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 106</ref> The following day they began the steep descent to the Mertz Glacier. After the sledges several times overtook the dogs, the huskies were allowed to run free down the slope.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 108">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 108</ref>
Following a particularly steep descent the following day, half of Mawson's team of dogs—reattached to his sledges—were almost lost when they fell into a crevasse. They were hauled out, but Mawson decided to camp when one of the dogs, Ginger Bitch, gave birth to the first in a litter of fourteen pups.{{refn|Mawson's diary on 21 November records "Dogs fed with Jappy [one of the other dogs, killed the previous day] and pups".<ref name="Mawson p. 134">Mawson (1988), p. 134</ref> Mawson biographer Philip J. Ayres suggests the sledge dogs' consumption of the pups was "normal in these conditions".<ref name="Ayres p. 72">Ayres (1999), p. 72</ref>|group="nb"}}<ref name="Bickel pp. 99-100">Bickel (2000), pp. 99–100</ref>
Over the next several days, the party continued across the glacier. They developed a method of crossing the many crevasses; the forerunner, on skis, would cross the snow covering the hole (the lid), and once across the first of the two dog teams would follow. Only after the first dog team was across would the second follow, "otherwise", wrote Mawson, "the dogs in the rear would make a course direct for wherever the front dogs happened to be, cutting across corners and probably dragging their sledge sideways into a crevasse".<ref name="Riffenburgh pp. 109-110">Riffenburgh (2009), pp. 109–110</ref> But despite their precautions Ninnis fell down and was rescued from three crevasses, once when they found they had pitched their tent on its lip.<ref name="Riffenburgh pp. 108-109">Riffenburgh (2009), pp. 108–109</ref>
After Mawson slipped into a crevasse, they began to tie themselves to their sledges as a precaution.<ref name="Bickel p. 102">Bickel (2000), p. 102</ref> Ninnis developed [[photokeratitis]] (snow-blindness), which Mawson treated with [[zinc sulfate]] and [[cocaine hydrochloride]].<ref name="Mawson p. 146">Mawson (1996), p. 146</ref> They were also losing dogs; one broke his leg and was shot, another fell ill, and a third was lost down a crevasse.<ref name="Bickel p. 101">Bickel (2000), p. 101</ref> On 24 November, the party reached the eastern side of the glacier and ascended to the plateau.<ref name="Mawson p. 151">Mawson (1996), p. 151</ref>
On level ground again, they began to make quick progress. They awoke on the morning of 27 November to find another glacier (later known as the [[Ninnis Glacier]]) far larger than the first.<ref name="Bickel p. 105">Bickel (2000), p. 105</ref><ref name="Riffenburgh p. 110">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 110</ref> As with the first glacier, they had to unhitch the dogs from the sledges and slowly make the treacherous descent. Once at the bottom of the glacier they spent four days crossing fields of crevasses, battling strong winds and poor light that made navigation difficult.<ref name="Riffenburgh pp. 110-111">Riffenburgh (2009), pp. 110–111</ref>
In the harsh conditions, the dogs began to grow restless; one of them, Shackleton, tore open the men's food bag and devoured a {{convert|2.5|lb|adj=on}} pack of butter, crucial for their nourishment to supplement the [[hoosh]].<ref name="Bickel p. 106">Bickel (2000), p. 106</ref> On 30 November, the party reached the eastern limit of the glacier and began the ascent to the plateau beyond, only to find themselves confronted at the top by [[sastrugi]] so sharp-edged the dogs were useless.<ref name="Bickel p. 107">Bickel (2000), p. 107</ref> Worse still, temperatures rose to {{convert|1|°C}}, melting the snow and making pulling difficult; the party switched to travelling at night to avoid the worst of the conditions.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 112">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 112</ref>
From atop the ridge on the eastern side of the Ninnis Glacier, Mawson began to doubt the accuracy of the reports of land to the east by [[Charles Wilkes]] during the 1838–42 [[United States Exploring Expedition]].<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 112"/> By Wilkes' reckoning, Mawson recorded in his diary, "We now appear to be off the real continent edge."<ref name="Mawson p. 140">Mawson (1988), p. 140</ref> Concerned about overlap with Madigan's party to the north, he turned his party south. They made good progress initially, but beginning on 6 December a blizzard confined them to their tent for three days.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 112"/> On 9 December, they set off again, but Ninnis was struggling. He had developed [[neuralgia]] on the left side of his face and a [[whitlow]] on one of his fingers. The latter was making sleep difficult for him, and on 13 December Mawson lanced the finger.<ref name="Bickel pp. 109-112">Bickel (2000), pp. 109–112</ref>
=== Death of Ninnis === [[File:B. E. S. Ninnis.jpg|thumb|upright=1|Ninnis, in his Royal Fusilier uniform before the expedition. "We could do nothing," wrote Mertz in his diary after Ninnis' death. "We were standing, helplessly, next to a friend's grave, my best friend of the whole expedition."<ref name="Catastrophe">{{cite web |url= http://mawsonshuts.antarctica.gov.au/cape-denison/mawsons-fatal-journey |title= Mawson's fatal journey |work= Mawson's Huts Foundation |publisher= Australian Antarctic Division |accessdate= 30 March 2012}}</ref>]] On the evening of 13 December Mawson and Mertz rearranged the sledges. The rear-most sledge, which had carried the most weight, was well-worn, and they decided to abandon it. The remaining supplies were re-distributed between the remaining two sledges. Most of the important supplies—the tent and most of the food—were stored on the new rear sledge;<ref name="Bickel p. 113">Bickel (2000), p. 113</ref> if they were to lose a sledge down a crevasse, they reasoned, it would be the front, less-vital sledge.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 115">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 115</ref> As the rear sledge was heavier, the strongest of remaining dogs were assigned to pull it.<ref name="Bickel p. 113"/> At the camp they left a small amount of supplies, including the abandoned sledge and a tent cover, without the floor or poles.<ref name="Hall and Scanlan, p. 126">Hall and Scanlan (2000), p. 126</ref>
By noon the next day they had covered {{convert|311|mi}} from the Cape Denison hut.<ref name="Ayres p. 72"/> Mertz was ahead on skis, breaking trail. Mawson sat on the first sledge; Ninnis walked beside the second.<ref name="Hall and Scanlan, p. 126"/> In his diary that night, Mertz recounted:
{{quote|Around 1 pm, I crossed a crevasse, similar to the hundred previous ones we had passed during the last weeks. I cried out "crevasse!", moved at right angle, and went forward. Around five minutes later, I looked behind. Mawson was following, looking at his sledge in front of him. I couldn't see Ninnis, so I stopped to have a better look. Mawson turned round to know the reason I was looking behind me. He immediately jumped out of his sledge, and rushed back. When he nodded his head, I followed him, driving back his sledge.<ref name="Catastrophe"/>}}
Ninnis, his sledge and dog team had fallen through a crevasse {{convert|11|ft}} wide with straight, ice walls.<ref name="Mawson p. 148">Mawson (1988), p. 148</ref> On a ledge deep in the hole, Mawson and Mertz could see the bodies of two dogs—one still alive, but seriously injured—and the remains of Ninnis' sledge. There was no sign of their companion.<ref name="Bickel p. 119">Bickel (2000), p. 119</ref> They measured the distance to the ledge as {{convert|150|ft}}, too far for their ropes to reach.<ref name="Ayres p. 73">Ayres (1999), p. 73</ref> "Dog ceased to moan shortly", wrote Mawson in his diary that night. "We called and sounded for three hours, then went a few miles to a hill and took position observations. Came back, called & sounded for an hour. Read the burial service."<ref name="Mawson p. 148"/>
== Return == Along with the heavy-weather tent, most of their own food and all of the dogs' food, they had lost the [[pickaxe]], the shovel, and Mertz's [[Waterproofing|waterproof]] overpants and helmet. On Mawson's sledge they had their stove, fuel, [[sleeping bag]]s, and ten days' worth of food.<ref name="Hall and Scanlan, p. 126"/><ref name="Bickel p. 121">Bickel (2000), p. 121</ref> Their best immediate hope was to reach the camp of two days earlier where they had left the abandoned sledge and supplies, {{convert|15|mi}} west. They reached it in five-and-a-half-hours, where Mertz used the tent cover, with the runners from the abandoned sledge and a ski as poles, to erect a shelter.<ref name="Ayres p. 74">Ayres (1999), p. 74</ref>
They were faced with two possible routes back to Cape Denison. The first option was to make for the coast, where they could supplement their meagre supplies with [[seal meat]], and hope to meet with Madigan's party; that would considerably lengthen the journey, and the sea ice in summer could not be relied on. Or, pushing slightly to the south of their outward route, they could hope to avoid the worst of the crevasses and aim for speed.<ref name="Ayres pp. 74-75">Ayres (1999), pp. 74–75</ref> Mawson chose the inland route, which meant that in the absence of fresh seal meat they would have to resort to [[dog meat|eating their remaining dogs]].<ref name="Ayres p. 75">Ayres (1999), p. 75</ref> The first dog—George—was killed the following morning, and of his meat some was fried for the men and the rest fed to the now starving dogs. "On the whole it was voted good" wrote Mawson of the meat, "though it had a strong, musty taste and was so stringy that it could not be properly chewed".<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 121">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 121</ref>
[[File:Xavier Mertz.jpg|thumb|upright=1|Mertz, photographed before the expedition]]
Before setting off again they raised the flag—which they had forgotten to do at their furthest point—and claimed the land for the crown.<ref name="Ayres p. 75"/> With the temperature rising, they switched to travelling at night to take advantage of the harder surface the cold provided.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 121"/> With the five remaining dogs, Mawson and Mertz pushed on. Starving, the dogs began to struggle; two more—Johnson and Mary—were shot and divided between men and dogs over the following days.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 148">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 148</ref> Mawson and Mertz found most of the meat tough, but enjoyed the liver; it, at least, was tender.<ref name="Bickel p. 121">Bickel (2000), p. 121</ref> With the pulling power of the dogs now severely depleted, Mertz stopped making trail and instead helped Mawson to pull the sledge. Despite the challenges, they made good progress; in the first four nights they travelled {{convert|60|mi}}.<ref name="Bickel p. 147">Bickel (2000), p. 147</ref> As they approached the Ninnis Glacier on 21 December, Haldane—once the largest and strongest of the dogs—was shot.<ref name="Mawson p. 152">Mawson (1988), p. 152</ref><ref name="Riffenburgh pp. 123–124">Riffenburgh (2009), pp. 123–124</ref>
=== Death of Mertz === Both men were suffering, but Mertz in particular started to feel ill. He complained of stomach pains, and this began to slow them down.<ref name="Bickel p. 153">Bickel (2000), p. 153</ref> Pavlova was killed, leaving only one remaining dog. Mawson decided to lighten their sledge, and much of the equipment—including the camera, photographic films, and all of the scientific equipment save the [[theodolite]]—was abandoned.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 125">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 125</ref> On 29 December, the day they cleared the Ninnis Glacier, the last dog was killed. Mawson recorded: "Had a great breakfast off Ginger's skull—thyroids and brain".<ref name="Mawson p. 155">Mawson (1988), p. 155</ref><ref name="Riffenburgh p. 127">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 127</ref> Two days later Mawson recorded that Mertz was "off colour"; Mertz wrote that he was "really tired [and] shall write no more".{{refn|Mertz's last entry in his diary was on 1 January, a week before his death. After he died, Mawson tore the remaining blank pages from the diary to save weight.<ref name="Ayres p. 76">Ayres (1999), p. 76</ref>|group="nb"}}<ref name="Ayres p. 76"/><ref name="Mawson p. 156">Mawson (1988), p. 156</ref>
They made {{convert|5|mi}} on 31 December, no progress for the following two days, and 5 miles more on 3 January. "[The] cold wind frost-bit Mertz's fingers" recorded Mawson, "and he is generally in a very bad condition. Skin coming off legs, etc—so had to camp though going was good."<ref name="Mawson p. 156"/> Not until 6 January did they make any more progress; they went {{convert|2|mi}} before Mertz collapsed.<ref name="Ayres pp. 76-77">Ayres (1999), pp. 76–77</ref> The following day Mawson placed Mertz onto the sledge in his sleeping bag and continued, but was forced to stop and camp when Mertz's condition again deteriorated. Mawson recorded:
{{quote|He is very weak, becomes more and more delirious, rarely being able to speak coherently. He will eat or drink nothing. At 8 pm he raves & breaks a tent pole. Continues to rave & call 'Oh Veh, Oh Veh' [''O weh!'', 'Oh dear!'] for hours. I hold him down, then he becomes more peaceful & I put him quietly in the bag. He dies peacefully at about 2 am on morning of 8th.<ref name="Mawson p. 158">Mawson (1988), p. 158</ref><ref name="Ayres p. 77">Ayres (1999), p. 77</ref>}}
Strong winds prevented Mawson from continuing for two days. Instead, he prepared for travelling alone, removing the rearmost half from the sledge, and rearranging its cargo. To save having to carry excess [[kerosene]] for the stove, he boiled the remainder of the dog meat. Dragging Mertz's body in the sleeping bag from the tent, Mawson constructed a rough cairn from snow blocks to cover it, and used two spare beams from the sledge to form a cross, which he placed on the top. The following day he read the burial service.<ref name="Riffenburgh pp. 131–133">Riffenburgh (2009), pp. 131–133</ref>
=== Alone === [[File:Mawson's half sledge.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Mawson's half sledge, which he used during the final stage of the journey]] As the weather cleared on 11 January, Mawson continued west, estimating the distance back to Cape Denison at {{convert|100|mi}}.<ref name="Mawson p. 158"/><ref name="Ayres p. 79">Ayres (1999), p. 79</ref> He travelled 2 miles before pain in his feet forced him to stop; he found that the soles of his feet had separated as a complete layer. Applying [[lanolin]] to his feet and wrapping them in several pairs of socks under his boots, he continued.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 135">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 135</ref> "My whole body is apparently rotting from lack of nourishment" he recorded, "frost-bitten fingertips festering, mucous membrane of nose gone, saliva glands of mouth refusing duty, skin coming off whole body".<ref name="Mawson p. 159">Mawson (1988), p. 159</ref> Averaging around 5 miles a day, he began to cross the Mertz Glacier. On 17 January he broke through the lid of a crevasse, but the rope around his waist held him to the sledge and halted his fall.<ref name="Bickel pp. 198-199">Bickel (2000), pp. 198–199</ref>
{{quote|I had time to say to myself "So this is the end" [Mawson recorded], expecting every moment the sledge to crash on my head and both of us to go to the bottom unseen below. Then I thought of the food left uneaten in the sledge—and, as the sledge stopped without coming down, I thought of Providence again giving me a chance. The chance looked very small as the rope had sawed into the overhanging lid, my finger ends all damaged, myself weak ... With the feeling that Providence was helping me I made a great struggle, half getting out, then slipping back again several times, but at last just did it. Then I felt grateful to Providence ... who has so many times already helped me.<ref name="Mawson pp. 161–162">Mawson (1988), pp. 161–162</ref><ref name="Ayres pp. 79–80">Ayres (1999), pp. 79–80</ref>}}
To save himself from future crevasses, Mawson constructed a rope ladder, which he carried over his shoulder and was attached to the sledge. It paid off almost immediately, and twice in the following days it allowed him to climb from crevasses.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 139">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 139</ref> Once out of the Mertz Glacier his mileage increased, and on 28 January Madigan Nunatak came into view. The following day, after travelling 5 miles, a cairn covered with black cloth appeared about {{convert|300|yd}} to his right. In it he found food and a note from [[Archibald Lang McLean]], who along with [[Frank Hurley]] and [[Alfred Hodgeman]] had been sent out by ''Aurora'''s captain [[John King Davis]] to search for the Far Eastern Party.<ref name="Ayres p. 81">Ayres (1999), p. 81</ref><ref name="Bickel p. 215">Bickel (2000), p. 215</ref>
From the note, Mawson learned he was {{convert|21|mi}} south-east of Aladdin's Cave, and near two further food depots. The note also reported on the other parties of the expedition—all had returned to the hut safely—and on [[Roald Amundsen]]'s [[Amundsen's South Pole expedition|attainment of the South Pole]] in December 1911.<ref name="Ayres p. 81"/> The cairn had been left there just six hours before, when the three men had returned to the hut.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 142">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 142</ref> Struggling on his injured feet and lacking [[crampons]] (he had thrown his away after he crossed the Mertz Glacier), Mawson took three days to reach Aladdin's Cave.<ref name="Ayres p. 81"/><ref name="Riffenburgh p. 143">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 143</ref>
Although supplies had been left in Aladdin's Cave—including fresh fruit—there were not the spare crampons he had expected. Without them he could not hope to descend the steep ice slope to the hut, and so he began to fashion his own, collecting nails from every available source and hammering them into wood from spare packing cases.<ref name="Bickel pp. 229–230">Bickel (2000), pp. 229–230</ref><ref name="Riffenburgh p. 144">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 144</ref> Even when completed, a blizzard confined him to the cave, and only on 8 February was he able to begin the descent. Nearing the hut, he was spotted by three men working outside, who rushed up the hill to meet him.<ref name="Ayres p. 82">Ayres (1999), p. 82</ref>
== Aftermath == [[File:Douglas Mawson recuperating.jpg|thumb|upright=1|Mawson shortly after his return to Cape Denison]] The ''Aurora'' arrived at Cape Denison on 13 January 1913. When Mawson's party failed to return, Davis sailed her east along the coast as far as the Mertz Glacier tongue, searching for the party. Finding no sign and reaching the end of the navigable ice-free water, they returned to Cape Denison. The oncoming winter concerned Davis, and on 8 February—just hours before Mawson's return to the hut—the ship departed Commonwealth Bay, leaving six men behind as a relief party. Upon Mawson's return, the ''Aurora'' was recalled by [[wireless]] radio, but powerful [[katabatic wind]]s sweeping down from the plateau prevented the ship's boat from reaching the shore to collect the men.<ref name="Ayres pp. 86–87">Ayres (1999), pp. 86–87</ref>
The ''Aurora'' returned to Cape Denison the following summer, in mid-December, to take the men home.<ref name="Bickel p. 257">Bickel (2000), p. 257</ref> The delay may have saved Mawson's life; he later told [[Phillip Law]], then-director of [[Australian National Antarctic Research Expeditions]] (ANARE), that he did not believe he could have survived the sea journey so soon after his ordeal.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 154">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 154</ref>
The cause of Mawson and Mertz's illnesses remains in part a mystery. At the time, McLean—the expedition's chief surgeon and one of the men who had remained at Cape Denison—attributed their sickness to [[colitis]]; Mawson wrote in ''The Home of the Blizzard'', his official account of the expedition, that Mertz died of fever and [[appendicitis]].<ref name="Bickel p. 259">Bickel (2000), p. 259</ref><ref name="Riffenburgh p. 136">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 136</ref> A 1969 study by [[John Burton Cleland|Sir John Cleland]] and [[Ronald Vernon Southcott|R. V. Southcott]] of the [[University of Adelaide]] concluded that the symptoms Mawson described—hair, skin and weight loss, [[Major depressive disorder|depression]], [[dysentery]] and persistent skin infections—indicated the men had suffered [[hypervitaminosis A]], an excessive intake of [[vitamin A]]. This is found in unusually high quantities in the livers of Greenland Huskies, of which both Mertz and Mawson consumed large amounts.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 136"/>
While hypervitaminosis A is the generally accepted medical diagnosis for Mertz's death and Mawson's illness, the theory has its detractors.<ref name="Riffenburgh p. 137">Riffenburgh (2009), p. 137</ref> Law believed it was "completely unproven ... The symptoms that were described are exactly the ones you get from cold exposure. You don't have to predicate a theory of this sort to explain the soles coming off your feet."<ref name="Ayres pp. 80–81">Ayres (1999), pp. 80–81</ref> A 2005 article in ''[[The Medical Journal of Australia]]'' by Denise Carrington-Smith suggested it may have been "the psychological stresses related to the death of a close friend and the deaths of the dogs he had cared for", and a switch from a predominately vegetarian diet that killed Mertz, not hypervitaminosis A.<ref name="Carrington-Smith p. 641">Carrington-Smith (2005), p. 641</ref>
[[File:Memorial cross for Mertz and Ninnis.jpg|thumb|upright=1|The memorial cross erected at Cape Denison in 1913 for Mertz and Ninnis]] Suggestions of [[cannibalism]]—that Mawson may have eaten Mertz after his death—surfaced during Mawson's lecture tour of the United States following the expedition. Several reports in American newspapers quoted Mawson as saying he considered eating Mertz, but these claims were denied by Mawson, who labelled them "outrageous" and an "invention".<ref name="Riffenburgh pp. 131–132">Riffenburgh (2009), pp. 131–132</ref> Mawson's biographers believe the suggestion of cannibalism is probably wrong; [[Beau Riffenburgh]] notes that Mawson nursed Mertz for days, even at the possible risk to his own life. Moreover, he notes, Mawson had no way of knowing why Mertz died; eating his flesh could possibly have been very dangerous.<ref name="Riffenburgh pp. 132–133">Riffenburgh (2009), pp. 132–133</ref> These sentiments are echoed by Philip Ayres, who also notes that with Mertz's death Mawson had sufficient rations without having to resort to cannibalism.<ref name="Ayres pp. 78–79">Ayres (1999), pp. 78–79</ref> Law, who knew Mawson well, believed "He was a man of very solid, conservative morals. It would have been impossible for him to have considered it."<ref name="Ayres p. 78">Ayres (1999), p. 78</ref>
In November 1913, shortly before the ''Aurora'' arrived to return them to Australia, the men remaining at Cape Denison erected a memorial cross for Mertz and Ninnis on Azimuth Hill to the north-west of the main hut.<ref name="Last gasp">{{cite web |url= http://mawsonshuts.antarctica.gov.au/cape-denison/mawsons-fatal-journey/last-gasp |title= Mawson's fatal journey: Last gasp |work= Mawson's Huts Foundation |publisher= Australian Antarctic Division |accessdate= 30 March 2012}}</ref> The cross, constructed from pieces of a broken radio mast, was accompanied by a plaque cut from wood from Mertz's bunk.<ref name="Bickel p. 254">Bickel (2000), p. 254</ref> The cross still stands, although the crossbar has required reattaching several times, and the plaque was replaced with a replica in 1986.<ref name="History">{{cite web |url = http://www.mawsons-huts.org.au/cms/history-of-mawsons-huts/ |title = History |work = Mawson's Huts Foundation |publisher = Australian Antarctic Division |accessdate = 7 July 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110706131725/http://www.mawsons-huts.org.au/cms/history-of-mawsons-huts/ |archivedate = 6 July 2011 |df = }}</ref> The two glaciers the Far Eastern Party crossed—previously unnamed—were named by Mawson for Mertz and Ninnis.<ref name="AADC Mertz Glacier">{{cite web |url= http://data.aad.gov.au/aadc/gaz/display_name.cfm?gaz_id=593 |title= Mertz Glacier |work= Australian Antarctic Data Centre |publisher= Australian Antarctic Division |accessdate= 7 July 2011}}</ref><ref name="AADC Ninnis Glacier">{{cite web |url= http://data.aad.gov.au/aadc/gaz/display_name.cfm?gaz_id=478 |title= Ninnis Glacier |work= Australian Antarctic Data Centre |publisher= Australian Antarctic Division |accessdate= 7 July 2011}}</ref> At a celebration in the centre of Adelaide on his return from Antarctica, Mawson praised his dead companions: "The survivors might have an opportunity of doing something more, but these men had done their all".<ref name="Mawson's Reply">{{Citation |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article5418447 |title=Dr. Mawson's Reply |journal=The Advertiser |publisher=National Library of Australia |date=4 March 1914 |pages=16}}</ref>
Mawson's return was celebrated at the [[Adelaide Town Hall]], in an event attended by the [[Governor-General of Australia|Governor-General]], [[Thomas Denman, 3rd Baron Denman|Lord Denman]]. A typical speaker stated that "Mawson has returned from a journey that was absolutely unparalleled in the history of exploration—one of the greatest illustrations of how the sternest affairs of Nature were overcome by the superb courage, power and resolve of man".<ref name="Riffenburgh pp. 177–178">Riffenburgh (2009), pp. 177–178</ref> Including the Far Eastern Party, sledging parties from the Cape Denison base covered over {{convert|2600|mi}} of previously unexplored land; the expedition's [[Western Base Party]] on the [[Shackleton Ice Shelf]], under [[Frank Wild]], covered a further {{convert|800|mi}}.<ref name="Ayres pp. 95–96">Ayres (1999), pp. 95–96</ref>
The expedition was the first to use wireless radio in the Antarctic—transmitting back to Australia via a relay station established on [[Macquarie Island]]—and made several important scientific discoveries.<ref name="Mawson ADB">{{cite web |url= http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/mawson-sir-douglas-7531 |title= Mawson, Sir Douglas (1882–1958) |work= Australian Dictionary of Biography |publisher= Australian National University |author= Jacka, Fred |year= 1986 |accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref> First published in 1915, Mawson's account of the expedition, ''The Home of the Blizzard'', devotes two chapters to the Far Eastern Party;<ref name="Mawson pp. 214–273">Mawson (1915), pp. 214–273</ref> one contemporary reviewer commented that "undoubtedly to the general public the interest of the book centres in [this] moving account".<ref name="Mill p. 424">Mill (1915), p. 424</ref>
A later analysis by J. Gordon Hayes, while commending most of the expedition, was critical of Mawson's decision not to use skis, but Fred Jacka, writing in the ''[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]'', suggests that "for Mawson and Ninnis, who were manoeuvring heavy sledges, this would have been difficult much of the time".<ref name="Mawson ADB"/> In his 1976 foreword to Lennard Bickel's book on the Australasian Antarctic Expedition, explorer and mountaineer [[Edmund Hillary|Sir Edmund Hillary]] described Mawson's journey as "probably the greatest story of lone survival in Polar exploration".<ref name="Bickel p. x"/>{{clear}}
